results.abstract: Tech Sergeant Joseph Bannon, firefighter at New Jersey Air National Guard's 177th Figher Wing Base at Atlantic City International Airport, answers questions on emergency preparations in event space shuttle launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla, gets into trouble; photo (On the Map column) (M)

headline.main: Firefighters Are Ready to Rescue a Space Shuttle in Distress

results.snippet: Space shuttles  launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., commonly head south, but  for resupply missions to the International Space Station, they  head north. If such a  shuttle were to get in trouble, one of the three places on the East Coast where  it...
results.lead_paragraph: Space shuttles launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., commonly head south, but for resupply missions to the International Space Station, they head north. If such a shuttle were to get in trouble, one of the three places on the East Coast where it can make an emergency landing is the New Jersey Air National Guard's 177th Fighter Wing Base at Atlantic City International Airport. There, firefighters attached to the 177th Wing will get the astronauts out in a hurry. Tech. Sgt. Joseph Bannon, one of those firefighters, talked about the rescue plans. Q. Why did NASA choose the base at Atlantic City National International Airport?

results.abstract: Dr Pamela Hilliard Robertson, rookie astronaut, died on May 24 from injuries sustained two days earlier in small-plane crash outside Houston; she was 38 (S)
results.snippet: Dr. Pamela Hilliard Robertson, a rookie astronaut, died on May 24 from injuries sustained two days earlier in a small-plane crash. She was 38.    The accident took place just outside Houston, where Dr. Robertson was based at the Johnson Space Center...
results.lead_paragraph: Dr. Pamela Hilliard Robertson, a rookie astronaut, died on May 24 from injuries sustained two days earlier in a small-plane crash. She was 38. The accident took place just outside Houston, where Dr. Robertson was based at the Johnson Space Center of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

results.abstract: Daniel R Mintz article on using videoconferencing to maintain contact with his family, especially his 17-month-old daughter, while traveling on business (M)

headline.main: For a Dad, Videoconference Ties That Bind

results.snippet: WATCHING ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' in 1968, I marveled at the improbable scene of an astronaut making a video call to his family back on Earth. I never imagined that some 30 years later, I'd rush out of a business dinner in Hong Kong to make a...
results.lead_paragraph: WATCHING ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' in 1968, I marveled at the improbable scene of an astronaut making a video call to his family back on Earth. I never imagined that some 30 years later, I'd rush out of a business dinner in Hong Kong to make a videoconference call to my home in New York so that I could see my 17-month-old daughter, Noa, before her breakfast. In fact, I've used whatever new and clever technology I can, including digital photographs sent via e-mail and birthday notes faxed from airplanes, to try to make up for the fact that I periodically travel for my Asian private-equity business for weeks at a time. I miss my family a lot, particularly because Noa is at the stage in which important things happen every day -- new words, first steps, leaps of understanding.

results.abstract: Kennedy Space Center's new Dine With An Astronaut program for visitors noted (S)
results.snippet: A civilian who recently dined with astronauts paid $20 million for the privilege, and all he got to eat was space food. But in the Kennedy Space Center's new Dine With an Astronaut program, having a meal with an astronaut costs $33.25 and up, $22.65...
results.lead_paragraph: A civilian who recently dined with astronauts paid $20 million for the privilege, and all he got to eat was space food. But in the Kennedy Space Center's new Dine With an Astronaut program, having a meal with an astronaut costs $33.25 and up, $22.65 and up for ages 3 to 11, and the food sounds a lot more appetizing. Every Wednesday at 1 p.m. and Friday at 5 p.m. through Aug. 31 at the Space Center Visitor Complex an astronaut will dine with a group limited to 100 to allow for autographs, questions and photos. Typical fare: rotisserie chicken and a chocolate Space Shuttle. Tickets: (321) 449-4444 or www.kennedyspacecenter.com.

results.abstract: Joe Hagan article on 'outsider music,' the whole gamut of music created by people who are naive to idea of 'good' music and its techniques; notes that 26 outsiders are included in Irwin Chusid's book Songs in the Key of Z and its accompanying CD; photos (M)

headline.main: Untamed Sounds From Well Beyond the Margins

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: SONGS IN THE KEY OF Z (BOOK)

results.snippet: LAST month, I heard David Bowie's 1969 glam-rock classic ''Space Oddity'' as if for the first time. I'd heard the song on the radio before, of course; however, coming as it did, not from Mr. Bowie but from a choir of elementary school kids in a...
results.lead_paragraph: LAST month, I heard David Bowie's 1969 glam-rock classic ''Space Oddity'' as if for the first time. I'd heard the song on the radio before, of course; however, coming as it did, not from Mr. Bowie but from a choir of elementary school kids in a remote farm community in northern Canada, this was something new. Orchestrated in the late 1970's by a hippie music teacher named Hans Fenger, the scratchy recording sounded like a document of a clandestine event, as if Mr. Bowie's song had been co-opted for a cult ceremony. The instrumentation included electric guitar and the gamelan-like chimes invented for children by the composer Carl Orff. The lyric of the song's wayward astronaut, ''For here/ Am I sitting in my tin can/ Far above the moon,'' never resonated so genuinely.

results.abstract: Correction: June 8 obituary about astronaut misstated her given name; she was Dr Patricia Hilliard Robertson, not Pamela
results.snippet: An obituary on June 8 about an astronaut at the Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center in Houston misstated her given name. She was Dr. Patricia Hilliard Robertson, not Pamela.
results.lead_paragraph: An obituary on June 8 about an astronaut at the Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center in Houston misstated her given name. She was Dr. Patricia Hilliard Robertson, not Pamela.
